passages.title: Paired Passages: Starting from Scratch & Homemade Hot Sauce
passages.content: [This is a paired passage entry. The content is drawn from p3 and p4.]

questions.question:
Read the following dictionary entry.

stretch \ˈstrech\ n
1. something that seems beyond what is normal 2. the length or extent of an area 3. a continuous period of time 4. the amount of elasticity of something

Which definition best matches the way the word stretch is used in paragraph 9?
options: Definition 1
Definition 2
Definition 3
Definition 4
questions.correctAnswer: Definition 2

questions.question: What does the sensory language in paragraph 7 help the reader understand?
options: The doubts the author had about being able to complete his adventure
The difficulty the author had pushing his wagon along the street
The distance between the author's house and the store
The details that the author remembers most vividly about that day
questions.correctAnswer: The details that the author remembers most vividly about that day

questions.question: Paragraphs 8 and 9 are mainly a description of —
options: the way the author and Kenny worked together to push the wagon along
the typical routine the author followed when he went to the grocery store
the different neighbors the author saw on the way to the grocery store
the safety measures the author took when walking along the shoulder of the road
questions.correctAnswer: the typical routine the author followed when he went to the grocery store

questions.question: Why did the author tell Kenny to turn the wagon around in paragraph 12?
options: He noticed that the groceries were not in the wagon with Kenny.
He was satisfied seeing only a small part of the other street.
He remembered that his mother was waiting for them to come home.
He decided that the new experience was not worth getting in trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: He decided that the new experience was not worth getting in trouble.

questions.question: The author describes his experience in a way that highlights —
options: how significant he thought going to the next street was when he was five years old
how long it took him to push the wagon to the neighborhood store when he was a boy
how important it was for him to take care of his little brother when they were younger
how much he worried about following his mother's rules when he was a child
questions.correctAnswer: how significant he thought going to the next street was when he was five years old

questions.question: What is the main theme of the selection?
options: Breaking the rules usually leads to a negative outcome.
People often have a strong desire to explore the unknown.
People tend to forget things when they are in a hurry.
Going to a new location can be an exciting experience.
questions.correctAnswer: People often have a strong desire to explore the unknown.

questions.question: What is the best summary of the selection?
options: When he was five years old, the author decided to venture down a forbidden street after buying some groceries for his mother. The author went partway down the new street but turned around because he was afraid of getting caught. When the shopkeeper waved him down on the way home, the author was sure his mother knew what he had done. Even though he wasn't in trouble, the author went straight home.

As a five-year-old, the author had wanted to explore the next street over, even though his mother thought the street was dangerous. One day, after he shopped for groceries at the corner store for his mother, he pushed his wagon down the forbidden street. He then turned around after only a few minutes.

When the author was five years old, his mother often asked him to take his wagon to the corner store down the street and pick up groceries for her. On one occasion the author tried to explore a different street on his way home. But because he forgot to take the groceries with him, he had to go back to the store, where the clerk was waiting outside for him.

One day when he was five, the author made a plan to explore a street after getting groceries for his mother. He took his wagon along his normal route to the store, but then he traveled down the other street after he bought the groceries. When he reached a vacant field, he thought he would be caught, so he returned home.
questions.correctAnswer: When he was five years old, the author decided to venture down a forbidden street after buying some groceries for his mother. The author went partway down the new street but turned around because he was afraid of getting caught. When the shopkeeper waved him down on the way home, the author was sure his mother knew what he had done. Even though he wasn't in trouble, the author went straight home.

questions.question: The details in paragraph 5 support the idea that —
options: humans use a lot of sarcasm and humor in everyday speech
miscommunication between humans is more likely when they cannot see facial expressions
language software is designed for communicating information rather than making jokes
human communication involves features that cannot easily be replicated by computers
questions.correctAnswer: human communication involves features that cannot easily be replicated by computers

questions.question: What is the main idea of paragraphs 7 and 8?
options: When people use speech-recognition applications, their privacy may be invaded.
As people talk more to computers, they may become less able to interact with humans.
Advances in technology may cause humans to lose their jobs to computers.
The use of speech-recognition technology poses a variety of potential problems.
questions.correctAnswer: The use of speech-recognition technology poses a variety of potential problems.

questions.question: According to the selection, speech-software developers are still striving to develop speech-recognition technology that —
options: can comprehend language as quickly as people speak it
helps people complete simple tasks on electronic devices
makes people feel as if they are speaking to a human
minimizes the need for most types of human interaction
questions.correctAnswer: makes people feel as if they are speaking to a human

questions.question: Which idea does the author emphasize throughout the selection?
options: Speech-recognition technology saves companies time and money.
The technology for speech-recognition systems is constantly improving.
Virtual personal assistants are an important achievement in talking computers.
The earliest speech-recognition systems had limited capabilities.
questions.correctAnswer: The technology for speech-recognition systems is constantly improving.

questions.question: The author's main purpose in writing this selection is to —
options: describe the history of and advances in speech-recognition technology
share concerns about problems with speech-recognition technology
suggest that consumers rely too much on speech-recognition technology
explain how speech-recognition technology understands human language
questions.correctAnswer: describe the history of and advances in speech-recognition technology

questions.question: Which sentence from the selection best explains why some people may prefer human-to-human communication?
options: Despite the efficiency of these systems, many people find them impersonal, stilted, and sometimes frustrating.
Even the advanced human-machine interfaces used today are unable to trick the judge consistently into thinking a computer is a human.
Simply put, the reason is that human beings rely on more than words to produce utterances and derive meaning from them.
While the potential for spontaneous communication between a human and a machine may seem exciting, this possibility concerns some people.
questions.correctAnswer: Despite the efficiency of these systems, many people find them impersonal, stilted, and sometimes frustrating.

questions.question: The author organizes the information in the selection mainly by —
options: explaining the development of speech-recognition technology over time
describing advancements in speech-recognition technology as well as some concerns about it
providing details about the technical processes that computers use to understand speech and construct a response
comparing the ways humans and computers interpret spoken language
questions.correctAnswer: describing advancements in speech-recognition technology as well as some concerns about it

questions.question: Which sentence from the selection reflects the author's opinion?
options: Today many voice systems can understand language when spoken at a normal conversational rate.
Others fear that machines will take over functions that were traditionally performed by humans, such as customer service.
This digital trail may lead to data mining, or the collection of large quantities of personal data.
For now, however, the continuing evolution of speech-recognition software is thrilling to behold.
questions.correctAnswer: For now, however, the continuing evolution of speech-recognition software is thrilling to behold.

questions.question: Which phrase from paragraph 1 best serves as an antonym context clue for the word refined?
options: weeding his garden
who loved numbers
let his hair run wild
sold his house
questions.correctAnswer: let his hair run wild

questions.question: Paragraphs 1 through 3 are important to the story because they establish that Anthony —
options: prefers talking to the serious Grandpa he has always known
is surprised to learn about Grandpa's change in behavior
thinks that Mom should not worry about Grandpa's new activities
wants Grandpa to teach him how to maintain a garden
questions.correctAnswer: is surprised to learn about Grandpa's change in behavior

questions.question: In paragraph 5, Anthony chooses not to mention the ready-made pesto most likely because he —
options: believes that Grandpa's homemade pesto will be more flavorful
realizes that Grandpa is excited about making homemade pesto
thinks it does not look as good as the kind he usually buys at the grocery store
knows that using a ready-made pesto means he would not get to spend time with Grandpa
questions.correctAnswer: realizes that Grandpa is excited about making homemade pesto

questions.question: By telling the story from the first-person point of view, the author helps the reader understand —
options: how Grandpa feels about living by himself in the old cottage
why Grandpa's life is different from that of his parents
why Anthony enjoys Grandpa's cooking despite the taste
how all the characters feel about their Italian heritage
questions.correctAnswer: why Anthony enjoys Grandpa's cooking despite the taste

questions.question: What can the reader conclude about Grandpa from his actions in the story?
options: He regrets his career working as a banker.
He misses living and working in the suburbs.
He wants to reconnect with his Italian roots.
He wishes his daughter would cook Italian food for him.
questions.correctAnswer: He wants to reconnect with his Italian roots.

questions.question:
Read this information about the origin of the word perennial.

from Latin per-, meaning "throughout," + annus, meaning "year"

This information helps the reader determine that the word perennial in line 9 means —
options: not measurable
highly desirable
not easily avoided
continually present
questions.correctAnswer: continually present

questions.question: In the first stanza, the poet uses the metaphor of a hunt to emphasize that Mother is —
options: eager to finish her shopping and begin preparing the hot sauce
competing with other shoppers at the market for the best produce
determined to find just the right peppers to use in her hot sauce
skillful at combining many different ingredients in her recipes
questions.correctAnswer: determined to find just the right peppers to use in her hot sauce

questions.question: The words "patiently," "pounds," and "promptly" in the second stanza highlight Mother's —
options: desire to improve
devotion to her task
need for assistance
eagerness to finish her work
questions.correctAnswer: devotion to her task

questions.question: The poet uses present tense throughout the poem to convey that —
options: the speaker wants to visit the market again soon
the speaker wishes she were young again
the memory is vivid to the speaker
the memory makes the speaker feel childlike
questions.correctAnswer: the memory is vivid to the speaker

questions.question: Based on the details in the poem, the reader can conclude that Mother —
options: takes making hot sauce for her family seriously
spends the entire day making hot sauce
makes hot sauce for her family every day
wants her daughter to learn to make hot sauce
questions.correctAnswer: takes making hot sauce for her family seriously

questions.question: In what way are the topics of the story and the poem similar?
options: Both describe how to select a variety of ingredients when planning a meal.
Both highlight that young people know less about preparing food than adults.
Both show that homemade food tastes better than ready-made food.
Both provide details about preparing food in a traditional way.
questions.correctAnswer: Both provide details about preparing food in a traditional way.

questions.question: How does Anthony in the story differ from the speaker in the poem?
options: Anthony is amused by Grandpa's actions, while the speaker in the poem is concerned about Mother's behavior.
Anthony is thankful for Grandpa's efforts, while the speaker in the poem seems indifferent to Mother's work.
Anthony is surprised that Grandpa is cooking, while the speaker in the poem expects Mother to act the way she does.
Anthony is encouraging of Grandpa's new interests, while the speaker in the poem worries about Mother's traditional ways.
questions.correctAnswer: Anthony is surprised that Grandpa is cooking, while the speaker in the poem expects Mother to act the way she does.

questions.question: Unlike Grandpa in the story, Mother in the poem —
options: prepares the hot sauce to be used for dinner that night
makes her homemade sauce with freshly picked produce
uses special equipment to make her homemade sauce
seems very experienced at preparing her own sauce
questions.correctAnswer: seems very experienced at preparing her own sauce

questions.question: The ending of the story and the ending of the poem are similar because both Anthony and the speaker —
options: wish they could help their family member perform a routine chore
take comfort in observing a family member doing something with love
learn how to do something interesting by watching a family member
understand the significance of a specific cultural tradition
questions.correctAnswer: take comfort in observing a family member doing something with love

questions.question: Grandpa in the story and Mother in the poem would most likely agree that —
options: cooking meals with others takes too much time
living in the country is better than living in the city
making food from scratch can be very satisfying
doing something the old way is always better
questions.correctAnswer: making food from scratch can be very satisfying

questions.question: Scaturro and Brown filmed their adventure most likely because they —
options: believed their journey down the Nile River would bring them more fame
hoped it would help promote efforts to clean and protect the areas along the Nile River
wanted people around the world to appreciate the beauty and diversity of the Nile River
thought the publicity would encourage more tourists to visit the Nile River
questions.correctAnswer: wanted people around the world to appreciate the beauty and diversity of the Nile River

questions.question: Which detail from paragraph 2 supports the idea that the Nile River spans diverse areas?
options: The Nile River is the longest river in the world, measuring about 4,100 miles in length.
The White Nile begins in Rwanda, and the Blue Nile begins in Ethiopia.
The two main tributaries of the Nile River meet in Sudan to form one river.
The Nile River flows through cities as well as remote deserts and mountain regions.
questions.correctAnswer: The Nile River flows through cities as well as remote deserts and mountain regions.

questions.question: Based on paragraphs 3 and 4, what can the reader infer about navigating the Nile River?
options: Many explorers have failed in their attempts to complete the trip.
It is a challenging endeavor even for experienced adventurers.
Preparing for the journey can take many months of planning.
It is best to make the expedition with a small crew.
questions.correctAnswer: It is a challenging endeavor even for experienced adventurers.

questions.question: Based on paragraph 5, the reader can infer that for Scaturro and Brown —
options: the satisfaction of traveling the Nile River outweighed the dangers it presented
the Nile River provided a place to get away from modern life
the journey along the Nile River was a challenging test of their survival skills
the sights along the Nile River were better experienced on film than in person
questions.correctAnswer: the satisfaction of traveling the Nile River outweighed the dangers it presented

questions.question: The details in paragraph 6 support the idea that —
options: the Nile River and its main tributaries flow through many African countries
population growth along the Nile has caused the river to become polluted
the Nile River serves as a shared foundation for many diverse African cultures
the largest cities along the Nile River are located in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: the Nile River serves as a shared foundation for many diverse African cultures

questions.question: The map of the Nile River Valley is included in the selection to —
options: indicate why the Blue Nile is considered the primary source of the river
show the long and winding course of the river
emphasize that the river is important to all the countries it flows through
highlight the most popular locations along the river
questions.correctAnswer: show the long and winding course of the river

questions.question: The author organizes the information in the selection mainly by —
options: explaining why Scaturro and Brown wanted to explore the Nile River and then giving details about how they prepared for the journey
comparing the Nile River with other rivers around the world and then discussing Scaturro and Brown's journey along the Blue Nile
stating that the Nile River is challenging to navigate and then sharing details about the difficulties Scaturro and Brown encountered on their journey
providing background information about the Nile River and then describing Scaturro and Brown's expedition
questions.correctAnswer: providing background information about the Nile River and then describing Scaturro and Brown's expedition

questions.question: The author's main purpose for writing this selection is to —
options: explain how the Nile River brings together a variety of cultures
describe the first expedition to travel the full length of the Nile River
discuss the dangers that travelers have encountered along the Nile River
provide information about the history of the Nile River
questions.correctAnswer: describe the first expedition to travel the full length of the Nile River

questions.question: What is the best summary of the selection?
options: Explorers Pasquale Scaturro and Gordon Brown traveled the length of the Nile River by boat. On their trip they saw mountains, deserts, gorges, waterfalls, and large cities. Their journey began in Ethiopia and ended in Egypt at the Mediterranean Sea. Some of the areas they traveled through were unsafe because of the harsh rapids, extreme heat, and hostile wildlife.

The Nile River flows through 11 African countries. The river is the world's longest and has been important to many civilizations for thousands of years. In 2004 explorers Pasquale Scaturro and Gordon Brown paddled the river and made a film about their trip. Sometimes their boats flipped in the water, and they were even attacked by a crocodile.

In 2004, Pasquale Scaturro and Gordon Brown became the first people to travel the entire Nile River by boat. Their 3,250-mile journey on the longest river in the world took four months. Though awed by the river's beauty, they also endured menacing conditions. Their trip helped them understand the significance of the Nile River to many African cultures.

A geophysicist and explorer named Pasquale Scaturro paddled the Nile River with filmmaker Gordon Brown in 2004. The river measures more than 4,100 miles and flows past a variety of landscapes as well as ancient cities and the Egyptian pyramids. An IMAX film was made about their journey.
questions.correctAnswer: In 2004, Pasquale Scaturro and Gordon Brown became the first people to travel the entire Nile River by boat. Their 3,250-mile journey on the longest river in the world took four months. Though awed by the river's beauty, they also endured menacing conditions. Their trip helped them understand the significance of the Nile River to many African cultures.

questions.question: Coach Wilson calls Teresa's mother before the tryout most likely to —
options: inform her that Teresa's tryout is probably going to be unsuccessful
tell her that Teresa will have to adjust to working with a new coach
persuade Teresa's mother to talk Teresa out of attending the tryout
give Teresa's mother directions to the training facility in Grand Prairie
questions.correctAnswer: inform her that Teresa's tryout is probably going to be unsuccessful

questions.question:
Read paragraph 3.

"But I was born to do the long jump. My instinct is to jump," Teresa said as she sat on a bench. "When I'm on the Olympic team, you'll see what I mean."

Teresa's comments influence the theme of the story because they show that she —
options: does not know a lot about long jumping
thinks that her coach does not give her useful advice
believes that she is a better long jumper than she actually is
feels as though she has to prove her abilities to others
questions.correctAnswer: believes that she is a better long jumper than she actually is

questions.question: Which event in the story causes Teresa to reevaluate her talent as a long jumper?
options: Teresa watches another girl jump a long distance.
Teresa's mother suggests that she practice more.
Teresa's first jump does not impress Coach Jennings.
Teresa declines to take her second jump.
questions.correctAnswer: Teresa watches another girl jump a long distance.

questions.question: The dialogue between Teresa and her mother after the tryout indicates that her mother —
options: believes that Teresa can make the Olympic team if she practices enough
knows that taking Teresa to the tryouts was a waste of time
thinks it was necessary to trick Teresa into taking long-jump practice seriously
wants Teresa to be honest with herself about her skill as a long jumper
questions.correctAnswer: wants Teresa to be honest with herself about her skill as a long jumper

questions.question: The story's third-person limited point of view gives the reader insight into —
options: the doubts Teresa's mother has about Teresa attending the tryout
Coach Jennings's thoughts about Teresa's jump at the tryout
the feelings Teresa has about her performance at the tryout
Coach Wilson's hesitation about sending Teresa to the tryout
questions.correctAnswer: the feelings Teresa has about her performance at the tryout
